Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Geography of Stress in the Woodfrog: Using Distributional Models to Predict the Relationship Between Population Health and Environmental Suitability

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Investigating the patterns and processes that determine the geographic distributions of organisms is a central goal of ecology and evolutionary biology, and an understanding of these processes is essential for scientists to predict how species ranges will respond to environmental change. This study uses modern ecoinformatic databases and spatially-explicit species distributional modeling to resolve important relationships between the environment and stress. The work will include measuring physiological stress in ways that are well established in biomedical research, but until now have not been applied to natural populations within an explicit geographic context. Measures of genetic variability (e.g., inbreeding and heterozygosity) will also be measured, as previous work has shown that populations at the edge of the species range have reduced genetic variability that is associated with lower quality habitats and reduced ability to survive or adapt to changes in environmental conditions. Thus, this project will be one of the first to unify physiological, genetic, and environmental assessments of stress in wild populations. While positive correlations among risk of population extinction, inbreeding and isolation, and physiological stress are widely assumed, direct comparisons among these ecological, genetic, and physiological measures of fitness have never been directly compared. The research focuses on the wood frog as a model system because amphibians are sensitive to environmental change, and they are the most threatened group of vertebrates on the planet. The result will be a statistical assessment of the relationship between environmental quality and stress across geographic space within the range of the wood frog. The goal is to provide a toolkit of fitness indicators for conservation biologists and biogeographers to use when predicting the geography of population health to make better predictions about whether populations will persist given the threats of climate change or habitat destruction.

This project aims to ground-truth a new technique that may become a useful tool in conservation biology to help assess population health and sub-lethal environmental stress in amphibians. This project provides the first integration of environmental endocrinology, population genetics, and spatially-explicit distributional modeling in a landscape-level stress assessment. This research will also enhance the education of both undergraduate and graduate students and train them to be integrative biologists who can use powerful bioinformatics databases to design studies and ask important conservation questions. Finally, in addition to research publications, presentations, and adding museum specimens to a natural history collection, a workshop on the Biogeography of Stress will be conducted to bring together research scientists, conservation biologists, and students to enhance dissemination of findings and synthesis of future directions in this field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The principal disciplinary field of this project is biogeography and as such the field necessarily encompasses theory from ecology, evolution, conservation, geology, and climatology. Biogeography is of renewed importance because of rapidly changing abiotic environments that influence the distribution of species. Our project sought to obtain empirical data to test major macroecological and biogeographic theories on why species are distributed where they are. In other words, in the absence of hard boundaries why are species distributed in unique ranges? Is this because of environmental gradients, where species experience stress and physiological limitations at the extreme ends? Is genetic diversity also limited at the range edge? These questions are predicted based on theory but are rarely tested empirically. In addition our work sought to determine if there are links between unique individual and population measures of stress like hormones and genetic diversity. Our work is novel and adds to the field of biogeography by integrating physiology into the field. This is the first study that examines baseline and stress induced hormone levels in multiple populations of a single species distributed across a large latitudinal gradient (spanning Alabama to Nova Scotia). By using spatially-explicit environmental models we also advance the field of biogeography by using a priori measures to assess the Core-Periphery hypothesis. Our data show that the environment, rather than simply geography, is most important in driving population measures of stress. We also are able to link these biogeographic trends in hormone levels, genetic diversity, and disease susceptibility. Therefore, we have extended the reach of biogeography. Our work will likely lead to additional studies that examine within-species variation in the genome and phenome. We believe this work will spur many new studies focused on the “Biogeography of Stress”. Bridging physiology, behavior, and evolution in a biogeographic context is new and exciting.

 

What are the impacts on other disciplines?

Our project specifically investigates the linkages between physiology, behavior, genetics, and geography. We predict that the field of neuroendocrinology and physiology will be impacted by our work because our studies are the first to investigate how “stress” varies with geography across a single species range. Other studies have investigated how temperate and tropical species differ, but our work is powerful in that we consider these patterns across an evolutionary lineage spanning multiple populations using an experimental approach. Our work is likely to impact disease ecology research. Our data on the geographic distribution of susceptibility to disease is a starting point for further studies that investigate the role of genetic diversity and ecological and evolutionary factors influencing organismal stress. 

For the field of neuroendocrinology, this work will provide a more landscape and environmental context for what has classically been a lab-dominated field. This is evident by both Rissler and Crespi being invited to the NSF/NASA Joint Workshop on Stress in the Healthy Organism in 2013. How to assess stress in natural populations of organisms under normal conditions will become an important research endeavor.

 

What is the impact on development of human resources?

 This work, both the research and broader impacts, has helped train two postdocs, multiple graduate students at two institutions, and many undergraduate researchers. In addition these students received interdisciplinary training that spanned biogeography, ecology, evolutionary genetics, endocrinology, and GIS modeling.
